This study covered the monitoring of the activities and services provided by the Tunisian ministry of environment, the National Environmental Protection Agency ANPE and the portal agridata.tn the open data portal of the ministry of a agriculture and validated by field interviews 
For the period from May 1,2019 to May 1, 2021, Tunisian inistutions don't publish any updated emissions data or information in any form 

Beside, the Tunisian national open data portal is down during the study period 

List of interviews

1.Houssem Hamdi, climate change activist and president of the Tunisian Ngo's Soli & green

2. Mrs Fathila Najeh, Data Analyst - Chief of Dissemination Database Unit at National Institute of Statistics

Birth information includes data about age, educational attainment, and ethnic and/or national group of mother.
Birth information includes data about age of father and place of usual residence.
Birth information includes data about site of delivery, attendant at birth, and month in which prenatal care began.

evidence.title: Loi n° 2020-46 du 23 décembre 2020, portant loi de finances pour l’année 2021
budget ouvert du Ministère des Finances de la Tunisie

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of data gaps.
responses.subquestion_text: This information is missing required data.
The availability of this data has been affected by government response to COVID-19.

This study covered the monitoring of the activities and services provided by The Tunisian presidency of government with a focus on the activities of the electronic governance unit, manager of the consultation.tn portal for the period from May 1,2019 to May 1, 2021 and validated by field interviews

Governmental decree No. 328 of 2018 dated March 29
2018 relating to the regulation of public consultations
The purpose of this government order is to establish controls
Organizing public consultations in order to:
Strengthening the administration's openness to its surroundings and enhancing communication mechanisms with
citizens and civil society,
- consolidation of the principles of transparency and participation in decision-making,
- strengthening the legitimacy of public policies,
- strengthening citizens' confidence in public administration,
-Improving the quality and efficiency of public policies.

The Governmental decree No. 328 of 2018 dated March 29
2018, Art. 13 (1) frame the information typology who need to be published and limit it to a summary report with relevant statistics
"

Reference 
(1) The coordinator prepares the report of the public consultation
Within a deadline not exceeding thirty (30) days from the date of closing the consultation.
The report must include statistical data about the consultation
and a summary of the proposals and observations emanating from it.
The report is published on the website of the respective structure
and on the National Consulting website.

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

Tunisia has adopted a panoply of laws to strengthen its capacities in transparency and citizen participation, law of protection of personal data and even an open data law number 3 of the year 2021.

However, it is important to note that none of the laws have taken measures ensuring that datasets and data processes are accessible to people with disabilities

On January 06, 2021, Tunisia adopted a government decree relating to open public data
The objective of this government decree is to organize the publication of public data in accordance with the principle of openness by default, with the aim of:
 Promote the principles of transparency and accountability,
 Support public participation in the development of public policies as well as the monitoring of their implementation and evaluation,
 Modernize the administration and improve the quality and efficiency of public services,
 Contribute to the establishment of an appropriate framework to promote economic development and create additional employment opportunities, in particular by stimulating the creation of start-ups which work for the creation of new innovative use cases by exploiting public data.

list of interviews

1. Mrs Fathila Najeh, Data Analyst - Chief of Dissemination Database Unit at National Institute of Statistics


2. Hatem chaktoun, Secretary General of the Tunisian Democratic Transition Observatory and coordinator of the open gov academy at university of Manar 1


3. Esghaier Chamakh ,HR & Democracy Defender

There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

Tunisia has adopted a panoply of laws to strengthen its capacities in transparency and citizen participation and to align itself with the constitutional right of the citizen, mainly the law of access to information, law of protection of personal data. , and even an open data law number 3 of the year 2021.

Finally on April 7, 2021, a decree was published in the official journal relating to the electronic exchange of data between the structures and their interlocutors and between them.

list of interviews

1:Esghaier Chamakh ,HR & Democracy Defender 


2. Mrs Fathila Najeh, Data Analyst - Chief of Dissemination Database Unit at National Institute of Statistics



Citation : According to Mrs Fadhia Najeh, Data Analyst - Chief of Dissemination Database Unit at National Institute of Statistics, the Government decree n ° 2021-3 of January 6, 2021, relating to open public data, frame the data standards, map the different stakeholders of the Tunisian ecosystem and provide a clear framework for data sharing between the data actors;

3. Hatem chaktoun, Secretary General of the Tunisian Democratic Transition Observatory and coordinator of the open gov academy at university of Manar 1


citation 

Accroding to  Mr hatem chakroun , secretary General of the Tunisian Democratic Transition Observatory and coordinator of the open gov academy at university of Manar 1

"The open data decree as well the decree relating to the electronic exchange of data between structures and their interlocutors published in the official journal on April 7, 2021,  
Indeed, these two decrees can help accelerate the digital transformation of the government which has not been able to take advantage of the pandemic like many other countries to set up and which unfortunately is very late and will therefore influence the progress of other laws, specially the access to information law and protection of personal data and open data. Beside the government has miss the opportunity created by the pandemic crises l to upgrade the public's services delivery"

This study covered the monitoring of the activities and services provided by The high authority for personal data protection, for the period from May 1, 2019 to May 1, 2021 and validated by field interviews

In Tunisia, a fairly extensive body of law
protects personal data:
• The 2014 constitution: Article 24: "The state protects the
privacy, the inviolability of the home and the secrecy of
correspondence, communications and data
personal "
• The Organic Law of 2004: Which includes the gaps and
imperfections
• The two implementing decrees of 2007
• Other laws relating to instances subject them to
the obligation to protect personal data:
ISIE, IVD,INLUCC, INPT

The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent.

The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.

The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.

The first article of the Tunisian constitution define the arabic as the official language of the country " Article 1 - Tunisia is a free, independent and sovereign State, Islam is its religion, Arabic its language and the Republic its regime" and the last point of Article 16 of the Open Data Law Decree recommends metadata in 3 languages: Arabic, French and English "Art. 16 - Organizations should adopt a common vocabulary for metadata associated with a dataset to allow the interoperability of data, and in particular the referencing of the datasets of each organization with the national portal.The unit develops the common vocabulary for metadata and publishes it in a procedure manual taking into account:  Compliance with international standards adopted in terms of metadata,  The need to be able to exchange certain data in an international framework,  The heterogeneity of published open data,  The existence of correspondences with other vocabularies,  The possibility of describing with this vocabulary a list of compulsory fields. The common vocabulary for metadata should be written in the Arabic and French languages ​​and ensure that it is provided in the English language. "

The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The framework requires collecting information on significant changes in assets and liabilities.
The framework requires disclosure of income and assets held by a public official's spouse, family members, or other intimates.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The framework requires the publication of income and asset declarations.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of lobbyists, lobbying clients, lobbying activities, and public officials.
The framework requires the collection and publication of the identities of lobbyists, lobbyist clients, and public officials who engage with lobbyists.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on lobbyists' goals for lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on timing of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on topics of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on how much money is spent on lobbying activities.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework does not require the disclosure, public or otherwise, of a donor's identity.
responses.subquestion_text: The framework requires donors' identities be made public.
The framework requires collecting specific information on financial contributions.
The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.
The framework requires collecting specific information on income and spending.
The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The framework requires regular updates, including updates in conjunction with campaigns and defined campaign schedules.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.

List of interviews : 
1: Mohamed MANSOURI, animator of the radio program "civic education" in radio nazaha, the community rafio  of the high independant regulator authority 
In Nazaha Radio, he is the animator of two radio emissions. The first correlates to the National Authority for the Prevention of Torture every Monday, and the second which aired every Friday relates to the
National Authority for the Protection of Personal Data,

3. Mrs Fathila Najeh, Data Analyst - Chief of Dissemination Database Unit at National Institute of Statistics

responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The framework covers the entire public sector.

responses.response_text: No evidence of actors or entities using this data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

This study covered the monitoring of the activities and services provided by the Tunisian ministry of  finance and the Tunisian court of audit  
And this for the period from May 1,2019 to May 1, 2021 and validated by field interviews

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of this use.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
